channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: I helped to build Taiwan’s Silicon Valley
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01468-1

Miin Wu, whose company, Macronix International, has played a seminal part in Taiwan’s semiconductor industry, explains why dust and vibration pose enormous challenges for running his factory.
item.dc:title: I helped to build Taiwan’s Silicon Valley
item.dc:creator: Margaret Simons

item.title: Air pollution in China is falling — but there is a long way to go
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01452-9

Easy gains from upgrading power-plant smokestacks will be strengthened only by deeper policy changes.
item.dc:title: Air pollution in China is falling — but there is a long way to go
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: What it’s like to be in the minority at a conference
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01467-2

Female and Black researchers describe the impacts of sexism and racism at conferences
item.dc:title: What it’s like to be in the minority at a conference
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: COVID's future: mini-waves rather than seasonal surges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01437-8

Three years after the start of the pandemic, SARS-CoV-2 shows no signs of settling into a seasonal pattern of spread, like influenza has.
item.dc:title: COVID's future: mini-waves rather than seasonal surges
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Online tools help large language models to solve problems through reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01411-4

The large language models popularized by chatbots are being taught to alternate reasoning with calls to external tools, such as Wikipedia, to boost their accuracy. The strategy could improve fact-finding outcomes, as well as online shopping.
item.dc:title: Online tools help large language models to solve problems through reasoning
item.dc:creator: Aleksandra Piktus

item.title: The sleight-of-hand trick that can simplify scientific computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01469-0

Computational environments and the tools to manage them can help researchers to deliver code that is reproducible, documented and shareable.
item.dc:title: The sleight-of-hand trick that can simplify scientific computing
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: ‘Intention is not action’: brain-research centre steps up quest for equality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01425-y

New institute aims to enshrine inclusivity in all aspects of neuroscience and psychology research.
item.dc:title: ‘Intention is not action’: brain-research centre steps up quest for equality
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Fund research on racism’s health impacts, says European group
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01448-5

A network of organizations urges the European Commission to recognize that discrimination can harm people’s well-being.
item.dc:title: Fund research on racism’s health impacts, says European group
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Audio long read: Conquering Alzheimer’s — a look at the therapies of the future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01351-z

Trial successes have raised hopes that the condition might eventually be preventable.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Conquering Alzheimer’s — a look at the therapies of the future
item.dc:creator: Alison Abbott
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: A foggy future for the Arctic means slower ship journeys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01449-4

Climate change is shrinking ice, fuelling fog formation over the Arctic Ocean.
item.dc:title: A foggy future for the Arctic means slower ship journeys

item.title: A new view of our senses, and the founding of Yosemite: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01466-3

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: A new view of our senses, and the founding of Yosemite: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Wind turbines are tough to recycle – this new chemistry could help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01476-1

A method for breaking down epoxies could stop wind turbine blades ending up in landfill.
item.dc:title: Wind turbines are tough to recycle – this new chemistry could help
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Canadian PhD students and postgrads plan mass walkout over low pay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01453-8

Academics are demanding a significant boost to government-sponsored fellowships and scholarships, which haven’t changed for decades.
item.dc:title: Canadian PhD students and postgrads plan mass walkout over low pay
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: How to keep Ukraine’s research hopes alive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01395-1

Ukrainian scientists reflect on their country’s invasion by Russia, how to halt a postwar brain drain, and how collaborations with Russian colleagues have suffered.
item.dc:title: How to keep Ukraine’s research hopes alive
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.title: ‘Armed groups entered the lab’: Sudan’s researchers flee violent military conflict
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01478-z

Clashes have left hospitals and universities without water and power — and vulnerable to takeover by armed groups.
item.dc:title: ‘Armed groups entered the lab’: Sudan’s researchers flee violent military conflict
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Racial inequalities in journals highlighted in giant study
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01457-4

Discrimination against members of under-represented groups in academic publishing leads to lower citation rates, fewer editorial-board positions and longer manuscript-review periods.
item.dc:title: Racial inequalities in journals highlighted in giant study
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Airborne sonar spies on what lies beneath the waves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01417-y

An aerial system can image objects submerged in either still or moving water.
item.dc:title: Airborne sonar spies on what lies beneath the waves

item.title: How this shrimp gets its brilliant white stripe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01415-0

Extremely white pigment stems from a peculiar arrangement of reflective molecules.
item.dc:title: How this shrimp gets its brilliant white stripe

item.title: US cancer deaths are falling — but not fast enough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01444-9

Models show that death rates must decline faster to meet Cancer Moonshot goals to cut deaths in half in 25 years.
item.dc:title: US cancer deaths are falling — but not fast enough
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Fish on dry land hint at why we blink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01416-z

Insights from mudskippers suggest that blinking is an adaptation to emerging from the sea.
item.dc:title: Fish on dry land hint at why we blink

item.title: Schrödinger’s cat is verified by a vibrating crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01414-1

The famed thought experiment, which posits that a cat can be alive and dead at the same time, is confirmed with classical evidence.
item.dc:title: Schrödinger’s cat is verified by a vibrating crystal

item.title: Daily briefing: The biggest Schrödinger’s cat ever
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01455-6

A sapphire crystal close to half the mass of an eyelash has been put in a quantum superposition state. Plus, black-hole image reveals turmoil around the abyss and how a human-made archipelago reveals the limits of rewilding.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The biggest Schrödinger’s cat ever
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Huge cache of mammal genomes offers fresh insights on human evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01446-7

The Zoonomia Project is helping to pinpoint genes responsible for animal-brain size and for human disease.
item.dc:title: Huge cache of mammal genomes offers fresh insights on human evolution
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: How I fused passions for art and medicine into a medical illustration career
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01432-z

Hillary Wilson contends that medicine needs more-diverse artwork from illustrators who bring varied perspectives.
item.dc:title: How I fused passions for art and medicine into a medical illustration career
item.dc:creator: Abdullahi Tsanni

item.title: Moon mission failure: why is it so hard to pull off a lunar landing?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01454-7

The ispace lander's failed touchdown highlights the challenges Moon landings pose, especially for private companies.
item.dc:title: Moon mission failure: why is it so hard to pull off a lunar landing?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Why it’s worth making computational methods easy to use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01440-z

Jean Fan and her team launched a digital campaign using YouTube, GitHub and blogs to make a computational-biology tool accessible to all. Here’s what they learnt.
item.dc:title: Why it’s worth making computational methods easy to use
item.dc:creator: Jean Fan

item.title: Synthetic data could be better than real data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01445-8

Machine-generated data sets have the potential to improve privacy and representation in artificial intelligence, if researchers can find the right balance between accuracy and fakery.
item.dc:title: Synthetic data could be better than real data
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: How Rosalind Franklin’s story was rewritten
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01443-w

Newly discovered documents reveal more about Rosalind Franklin’s role in solving DNA’s structure, and how multisensory experiences can create stronger memories in fruit flies.
item.dc:title: How Rosalind Franklin’s story was rewritten
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Hopes fizzle that a TB vaccine also fends off COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01426-x

The BCG injection failed to prevent COVID-19 in a large trial, contrary to preliminary evidence.
item.dc:title: Hopes fizzle that a TB vaccine also fends off COVID

item.title: Near-frictionless ion transport within triazine framework membranes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05888-x

The authors develop a strategy that allows the diffusion limit of ions in water to be approached for large-area, free-standing, synthetic membranes using covalently bonded polymer frameworks with rigidity-confined ion channels.
item.dc:title: Near-frictionless ion transport within triazine framework membranes
item.dc:creator: Peipei Zuo
Chunchun Ye
Zhongren Jiao
Jian Luo
Junkai Fang
Ulrich S. Schubert
Neil B. McKeown
T. Leo Liu
Zhengjin Yang
Tongwen Xu

item.title: Increased heat risk in wet climate induced by urban humid heat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05911-1

An analysis of data from urban and rural areas shows that in wet climates the net effect of temperature and humidity in urban areas is an increase in heat stress.
item.dc:title: Increased heat risk in wet climate induced by urban humid heat
item.dc:creator: Keer Zhang
Chang Cao
Haoran Chu
Lei Zhao
Jiayu Zhao
Xuhui Lee

item.title: Catalytic disconnection of C–O bonds in epoxy resins and composites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05944-6

The authors report a transition-metal-catalysed protocol for recovery of polymer building block bisphenol  A and intact fibres from epoxy composites, demonstrating that chemical recycling approaches for thermoset epoxy resins and composites are achievable.
item.dc:title: Catalytic disconnection of C–O bonds in epoxy resins and composites
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ahrens
Andreas Bonde
Hongwei Sun
Nina Kølln Wittig
Hans Christian D. Hammershøj
Gabriel Martins Ferreira Batista
Andreas Sommerfeldt
Simon Frølich
Henrik Birkedal
Troels Skrydstrup

item.title: Partitioning of diluted anyons reveals their braiding statistics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05883-2

A simple experimental method identifies the statistical phase of highly diluted abelian anyons weakly partitioned in fractional quantum Hall states and reveals their braiding statistics.
item.dc:title: Partitioning of diluted anyons reveals their braiding statistics
item.dc:creator: June-Young M. Lee
Changki Hong
Tomer Alkalay
Noam Schiller
Vladimir Umansky
Moty Heiblum
Yuval Oreg
H.-S. Sim

item.title: A ring-like accretion structure in M87 connecting its black hole and jet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05843-w

Spatially resolved images of M87 obtained at a wavelength of 3.5 mm in 2018 show a ring-like accretion structure, the inner (outer) edge of which connects the black hole (jet).
item.dc:title: A ring-like accretion structure in M87 connecting its black hole and jet

item.title: Multisensory learning binds neurons into a cross-modal memory engram
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06013-8

Multisensory learning improves subsequent memory performance, even for individual sensory cues, in Drosophila.
item.dc:title: Multisensory learning binds neurons into a cross-modal memory engram
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Okray
Pedro F. Jacob
Ciara Stern
Kieran Desmond
Nils Otto
Clifford B. Talbot

item.title: Photochemically produced SO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere of WASP-39b
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05902-2

Observations from the JWST show the presence of a spectral absorption feature at 4.05 μm arising from SO2 in the atmosphere of the gas giant exoplanet WASP-39b, which is produced by photochemical processes and verified by numerical models.
item.dc:title: Photochemically produced SO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere of WASP-39b

item.title: Cryptochrome–Timeless structure reveals circadian clock timing mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06009-4

Structural analysis of a protein complex in the circadian clock of Drosophila reveals how a light-sensing cryptochrome recognizes and engages its target.
item.dc:title: Cryptochrome–Timeless structure reveals circadian clock timing mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Changfan Lin
Shi Feng
Cristina C. DeOliveira
Brian R. Crane

item.title: Nodeless electron pairing in CsV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>-derived kagome superconductors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05907-x

The authors report that with the use of angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, nodeless electron pairing in CsV3Sb5-derived kagome superconductors can be observed directly.
item.dc:title: Nodeless electron pairing in CsV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>-derived kagome superconductors
item.dc:creator: Yigui Zhong

item.title: Tunable electron–flexural phonon interaction in graphene heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05879-y

Experimental observation and calculations show that broken reflection symmetry in graphene heterostructures allows tunable electron–flexural phonon coupling, providing a way to control quantum matter at the atomic scale.
item.dc:title: Tunable electron–flexural phonon interaction in graphene heterostructures
item.dc:creator: Mir Mohammad Sadeghi
Yajie Huang
Chao Lian
Feliciano Giustino
Emanuel Tutuc
Allan H. MacDonald

Kenji Watanabe
Li Shi

item.title: Tracing attosecond electron emission from a nanometric metal tip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05839-6

Two-colour modulation spectroscopy of laser field-driven electrons uncovers the suboptical-cycle strong-field emission dynamics from nanostructures with attosecond precision by measuring photoelectron spectra of electrons as function of the relative phase between the two colours.
item.dc:title: Tracing attosecond electron emission from a nanometric metal tip
item.dc:creator: Philip Dienstbier
Lennart Seiffert
Timo Paschen
Andreas Liehl
Alfred Leitenstorfer
Thomas Fennel
Peter Hommelhoff

item.title: Reducing brassinosteroid signalling enhances grain yield in semi-dwarf wheat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06023-6

A strategy that depends on attenuated brassinosteroid signalling is described for the design of semi-dwarf wheat varieties with improved grain yield compared with that of green revolution varieties.
item.dc:title: Reducing brassinosteroid signalling enhances grain yield in semi-dwarf wheat
item.dc:creator: Long Song

item.title: Dynamic crosslinking compatibilizes immiscible mixed plastics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05858-3

A new compatibilization strategy installs dynamic crosslinkers into several classes of binary, ternary and postconsumer immiscible polymer mixtures in situ, with the resulting compatibilized dynamic thermosets exhibiting intrinsic reprocessability and enhanced tensile strength and creep resistance.
item.dc:title: Dynamic crosslinking compatibilizes immiscible mixed plastics

item.title: Many-body cavity quantum electrodynamics with driven inhomogeneous emitters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05884-1

Under strong excitation, inhomogeneously broadened solid-state emitters coupled with high cooperativity to a cavity demonstrate collectively induced transparency and dissipative many-body dynamics, resulting from cavity–ion coupling.
item.dc:title: Many-body cavity quantum electrodynamics with driven inhomogeneous emitters
item.dc:creator: Mi Lei
Rikuto Fukumori
Jake Rochman
Bihui Zhu
Manuel Endres
Joonhee Choi
Andrei Faraon

item.title: Computational approaches streamlining drug discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05905-z

Recent advances in computational approaches and challenges in their application to streamlining drug discovery are discussed.
item.dc:title: Computational approaches streamlining drug discovery
item.dc:creator: Anastasiia V. Sadybekov
Vsevolod Katritch

item.title: Basin-wide variation in tree hydraulic safety margins predicts the carbon balance of Amazon forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05971-3

A pan-Amazon study of forests shows large variations in drought tolerance traits and finds that forests in regions of pronounced climate change are losing biomass and may be operating beyond their hydraulic limits.
item.dc:title: Basin-wide variation in tree hydraulic safety margins predicts the carbon balance of Amazon forests

item.title: Visualizing the disordered nuclear transport machinery in situ
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05990-0

Previously shown as a 60-nm hole in the nuclear pore complex, the transport machinery by FG-nucleoporins is mapped.
item.dc:title: Visualizing the disordered nuclear transport machinery in situ

item.title: Structural basis of BAM-mediated outer membrane β-barrel protein assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05988-8

The structural basis of the late-stage intermediate assembly of outer membrane β-barrel proteins mediated by the bacterial β-barrel assembly machinery is determined.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of BAM-mediated outer membrane β-barrel protein assembly

item.title: A druggable copper-signalling pathway that drives inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06017-4

Cellular uptake of copper(ii) by CD44 has a key role in regulating cellular plasticity via copper(ii)-dependent downstream signalling events.
item.dc:title: A druggable copper-signalling pathway that drives inflammation

item.title: Alternative CDC20 translational isoforms tune mitotic arrest duration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05943-7

Human cells modulate the duration of their mitotic arrest through the presence of conserved alternative CDC20 translational isoforms.
item.dc:title: Alternative CDC20 translational isoforms tune mitotic arrest duration
item.dc:creator: Mary-Jane Tsang
Iain M. Cheeseman

item.title: Long-range inhibition synchronizes and updates prefrontal task activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06012-9

Rule-shift behavioural experiments in mice demonstrate that callosal projections of parvalbumin-expressing neurons switch prefrontal circuits from maintenance mode to rule-learning mode by gating inputs from other callosal inputs that maintain previous rule representations.
item.dc:title: Long-range inhibition synchronizes and updates prefrontal task activity
item.dc:creator: Kathleen K. A. Cho
Jingcheng Shi
Aarron J. Phensy
Marc L. Turner
Vikaas S. Sohal

item.title: De novo design of protein interactions with learned surface fingerprints
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05993-x

A surface-centric approach captures the physical and chemical determinants of molecular recognition, enabling the de novo design of protein interactions and of artificial proteins with function.
item.dc:title: De novo design of protein interactions with learned surface fingerprints

item.title: Inhibitory input directs astrocyte morphogenesis through glial GABA<sub>B</sub>R
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06010-x

Inhibitory neuron activity is necessary and sufficient for astrocyte morphogenesis.
item.dc:title: Inhibitory input directs astrocyte morphogenesis through glial GABA<sub>B</sub>R
item.dc:creator: Yi-Ting Cheng

item.title: Tree diversity increases decadal forest soil carbon and nitrogen accrual
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05941-9

Analysis of data from the Canadian National Forest Inventory database suggests that greater tree diversity in natural forests is associated with increases in soil carbon and nitrogen stocks.
item.dc:title: Tree diversity increases decadal forest soil carbon and nitrogen accrual
item.dc:creator: Xinli Chen
Anthony R. Taylor
Peter B. Reich
Masumi Hisano
Han Y. H. Chen
Scott X. Chang

item.title: This pioneering nuclear-fusion lab is gearing up to break more records
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01424-z

Following the US National Ignition Facility’s breakthrough last year, Nature looks at what’s next.
item.dc:title: This pioneering nuclear-fusion lab is gearing up to break more records
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Rewilding the planet: how seven artificial islands could help a dying Dutch lake
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01370-w

An archipelago constructed of sand and mud is bringing new life to a dead lake but can this bold experiment have a lasting impact?
item.dc:title: Rewilding the planet: how seven artificial islands could help a dying Dutch lake
item.dc:creator: Aisling Irwin

item.title: Copper catalyses changes in cell state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01330-4

It emerges that copper ions found in cell organelles called mitochondria regulate the cellular changes that underlie transitions in cell state. A small molecule that inhibits copper-mediated catalysis can suppress the activation of immune cells called macrophages, conferring therapeutic benefits in models of acute inflammation.
item.dc:title: Copper catalyses changes in cell state

item.title: Private ispace Moon landing fails: researchers are investigating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01441-y

Mission control was unable to re-establish contact with the M1 spacecraft, and early signs suggest it crash-landed on the lunar surface.
item.dc:title: Private ispace Moon landing fails: researchers are investigating
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy
Miryam Naddaf

item.title: How flies remember a rich experience from its individual components
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01333-1

Multisensory information improves subsequent memory performance. In Drosophila flies, learning re-routes activity through neuronal networks in the brain such that individual components of a multisensory experience can trigger retrieval of the memory of the whole event. As a result, memory performance for both the combined and individual components of the experience is improved.
item.dc:title: How flies remember a rich experience from its individual components

item.title: Tree diversity enhances soil carbon and nitrogen sequestration in natural forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01321-5

Biodiversity experiments show that a high diversity of plants increases the accumulation of soil carbon and nitrogen, but whether such conclusions hold in natural ecosystems is debated. An analysis of Canada’s National Forest Inventory provides strong evidence that the build-up of soil carbon and nitrogen on a decadal timescale increased with improved tree diversity in natural forest ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Tree diversity enhances soil carbon and nitrogen sequestration in natural forests

item.title: New protein–protein interactions designed by a computer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01324-2

Creating protein interactions through computational design is a key challenge in the fields of both basic and translational biology. An approach that uses the machine-learned fingerprints of protein-surface features was used to produce synthetic proteins that engage immunotherapeutic or viral targets with binding affinities comparable to those of naturally occurring proteins.
item.dc:title: New protein–protein interactions designed by a computer

item.title: Daily briefing: Moon lander has been lost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01451-w

The lunar lander by Japanese firm ispace appears to have crash-landed. Plus, the risks of repeat COVID infections and a surprising galaxy with the ingredients for planet formation.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Moon lander has been lost
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Mixed plastics upcycled dynamically
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01352-y

Waste plastics contain immiscible polymers, making recycling challenging. A new additive enables the thermal reprocessing of mixed plastics into recyclable, high-performance materials.
item.dc:title: Mixed plastics upcycled dynamically
item.dc:creator: Mathieu L. Lepage
Jeremy E. Wulff

item.title: Chemist Charles Lieber avoids further prison time for lying about China ties
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01435-w

Ex-Harvard researcher was among the first academics tried under the now-defunct US China Initiative.
item.dc:title: Chemist Charles Lieber avoids further prison time for lying about China ties
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Are repeat COVID infections dangerous? What the science says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01371-9

Researchers disagree over how bad it is to be reinfected, and whether COVID-19 can cause lasting changes to the immune system.
item.dc:title: Are repeat COVID infections dangerous? What the science says
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Black-hole image reveals details of turmoil around the abyss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01442-x

Observations of galaxy M87 show how the black hole at its centre relates to a long-seen stream of superheated matter.
item.dc:title: Black-hole image reveals details of turmoil around the abyss
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: An unexpected timer for cell division
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01355-9

A serendipitous observation has revealed that cells make several versions of a key protein needed for cell division. The ratio of these protein isoforms influences how long division can be delayed when errors arise.
item.dc:title: An unexpected timer for cell division
item.dc:creator: Silke Hauf

item.title: Step-by-step assembly of a β-barrel protein in a bacterial membrane
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01327-z

Gram-negative bacteria that are resistant to multiple drugs cannot survive without the cell-surface machinery that builds a β-barrel pore structure from outer membrane proteins. Snapshots of different stages in the assembly process provide insights into this crucial mechanism, and could lead to the development of new antibiotics.
item.dc:title: Step-by-step assembly of a β-barrel protein in a bacterial membrane

item.title: Change YourView
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01318-0

The world is just enough.
item.dc:title: Change YourView
item.dc:creator: Matt Tighe

item.title: How trauma’s effects can pass from generation to generation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01433-y

Neuroepigenetics researcher Isabelle Mansuy investigates how life life experiences and environmental factors can shape not only us, but also our descendants.
item.dc:title: How trauma’s effects can pass from generation to generation
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Goldfish headgear reveals secrets of fish navigation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01427-w

Unprecedented pattern of brain activity is recorded in freely swimming fish.
item.dc:title: Goldfish headgear reveals secrets of fish navigation

item.title: Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01394-2

Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.dc:title: Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.dc:creator: Crow White

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: how several artists’ works mimic impressions made on the eye’s retina, and the curious effects of blue glass on colour

Green transition: create a European energy agency

item.title: Ancient Norse on Greenland imported wood from distant shores
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01412-3

Settlers brought in hemlock and other types of timber much earlier than previously realized.
item.dc:title: Ancient Norse on Greenland imported wood from distant shores
